Bachelor in Japanese. Can't find a job.

 Thing is, I decided my major when I was 17. It was dumb, but now I have this degree. I can't undo that. I graduated in 2009 and at that time I couldn't find a job either. I had the option to teach English in Japan but I thought that was a dead end so I chose instead to try to just work in the US. I thought maybe having a liberal_arts degree could get me a regular office job and I could work my way up in a company. I started out at temp agencies but it was too unstable. You could go months without income. Eventually I gave in and just started going to every company I could find and just asking if they're hiring. One company finally called me back, and gave me a warehouse job. I realized pretty quickly that there was no room for growth in this company so at first I decided to try going to school at night for IT. After failing intro to comp sci twice I gave up deciding it was really just too hard. Eventually I found Japanese recruiters and did get a job at a Japanese company in the US, however after a year of abuse and power harassment, I had what you could call a meltdown and walked out of the company. At this point I am 7 years removed from college. I have no useful skills, and my Japanese has only gotten worse. I've applied to Japanese recruiters in Japan but the consensus seems to be that bilingual is not considered a skill anymore and you need to couple it with something else. I don't understand why I can't get some kind of entry level office job in Japan, but I guess I can't. Friends have suggested getting an MBA but that seems like a waste of money and time. One thought I've had was going to language school for Japanese with what I have left of my savings so that at least I can take the JLPT and have that on my resume, but like I said, without another career oriented skill I think that might be a waste of time and money. I'm almost 30, and I have no job, no career, no career field, and my Japanese level is slipping. I'm still working with Japanese recruiters in the US, but to be honest, the impression I get is that they see that I quit my last job, and they don't want to hire me because of it. Do you have any advice? Any suggestions?
